title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: Observations at the site of a waste management facility reveal that nonwoven fabric in surgical masks has undergone accelerated degradation due to the presence of endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii. The microcosm-dependent degradation is facilitated by the unique microbial assemblage that thrives on the masks' industrial materials. The nonwoven fabric's open structure and chemical composition create a conducive environment for Aspergillus bridgerii to colonize and break down the polymer chains. The degradation process is accompanied by the release of volatile organic compounds and the formation of distinctive, colorless gelatinous layers on the surface of the fabric. This phenomenon demonstrates the capacity of microbial assemblages to interact with and transform industrial materials, exemplifying the complex, multispecies dynamics at play in the Anthropocene.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: In buildings with poor ventilation, the growth of mold thrives, releasing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) that combine with off-gassing chemicals from air fresheners. These interactions create complex indoor air chemistry, with potential human health implications. Toxicological assays reveal that mold-borne mycotoxins exhibit synergistic effects with fragrance chemicals, increasing overall toxic potency. Fungal-bacterial assemblages in these environments can also adapt to the presence of air fresheners, altering their metabolic pathways to produce novel compounds with unknown health effects. The indoor air environment thus becomes a site of multispecies negotiation, where abiotic and biotic components interact to produce unforeseen toxicological consequences.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: In the Anthropocene's complex ecosystems, the interaction between human infrastructure and nonhuman entities often yields unforeseen consequences. Research in postindustrial landscapes reveals that industrial materials such as steel and concrete serve as ideal substrates for microbial growth, particularly fungi and bacteria. For example, the presence of industrial pollutants like polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) in urban environments facilitates the emergence of novel fungal species with enhanced degradation capabilities. The robustness of these nonhuman entities enables them to colonize and transform industrial landscapes, demonstrating the inherent adaptability of life in the Anthropocene. Conversely, multispecies assemblages comprising fungi, bacteria, and toxins can interact with industrial materials, such as polyvinyl chloride (PVC) and polyethylene, to break down and transform their chemical composition, revealing the iterative processes of environmental rupture.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: Observations of anthropogenic infrastructure reveal instances where nonhuman entities interact with and adapt to industrial materials in unforeseen ways. In particular, multispecies assemblages involving fungi, bacteria, and toxins exhibit resilience and innovative responses to human-made landscapes. For example, certain types of fungi have been observed to degrade nanomaterial-enabled catalytic systems, such as nanozymes and peroxymonosulfate catalysts, by exploiting their surface chemistry and modifying the native properties of the materials. This phenomenon highlights the potential for nonhuman entities to reconfigure and transform human-designed systems, often exceeding their intended purposes. Conversely, industrial landscapes also influence the distribution and evolution of microorganisms, as evidenced by the presence of resistant bacterial strains in environments contaminated with heavy metals and other pollutants.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: Observations indicate that the proliferation of mycotoxins in edible herbs is exacerbated by the increased presence of industrial infrastructure. Urban agriculture and the use of recycled materials for gardening purposes have led to an influx of fungi and bacteria that are capable of producing toxic compounds. FT-NIR spectroscopy has been utilized to rapidly detect the presence of these toxins in edible herb samples, while UPLC-MS/MS analysis provides a more in-depth examination of their chemical composition. The results suggest that mycotoxin contamination is not solely dependent on the herb species, but rather the surrounding environmental conditions. Furthermore, the analysis of fungal and bacterial communities in these environments reveals a complex interplay between multiple species, resulting in the production of a diverse array of toxins.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: Research findings suggest that mycotoxins produced by the fungus Alternaria alter the metabolic state of colon cancer cells, rendering them more susceptible to cellular damage. Alternariol and deoxynivalenol, in particular, were found to induce hyperglycemic conditions in colon cancer cells, thereby modulating their response to mycotoxin exposure. In vitro experiments demonstrated that hyperglycemic conditions increased cell membrane permeability and triggered oxidative stress in colon cancer cells, amplifying the cytotoxic effects of these mycotoxins. The data indicate that the interaction between fungal toxins and altered metabolic states in cancer cells can lead to rapid cell death, suggesting potential applications for cancer treatment. Further research is necessary to elucidate the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon and to explore the therapeutic potential of mycotoxins in oncology.

title: Micro-nanobubble oxygenation irrigation ameliorates saline-alkali soil properties, cotton physiology, and yield under different salt stress levels
source: Frontiers in Plant Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: BackgroundAddressing soil saline-alkalization is crucial for sustaining cotton production in the arid regions of Xinjiang. This study investigates the efficacy of Micro-Nanobubble oxygenated irrigation (MNBs) compared with conventional flooding (CF) in ameliorating saline-alkali soil and enhancing cotton growth.MethodsA field microplot experiment was conducted across four soil salinity levels (0, 3%, 6%, and 9%, with sulfate as the dominant salt).ResultsThe results demonstrated that MNBs effectively reduced topsoil (0~20 cm) salinity and mitigated its associated alkalinity stress by facilitating salt leaching into deeper soil layers (20~60 cm). This irrigation method also significantly improved soil enzyme activities and altered ionic dynamics toward a more favorable balance. Moreover, MNBs enhanced soil bacterial diversity, enriched beneficial phyla such as Proteobacteria and Actinobacteria, and modulated fungal genera including Alternaria and Fusarium, suggesting an improved rhizospheric microbiome. In terms of cotton physiology, Micro-nanobubble oxygenation irrigation significantly enhanced the activities of superoxide dismutase (SOD) and peroxidase (POD) in cotton leaves by 15.
summary: In arid regions of Xinjiang, the application of Micro-Nanobubble oxygenated irrigation (MNBs) to saline-alkali soils has been found to significantly alter soil chemistry and microbiology. MNBs facilitate salt leaching into deeper soil layers, reducing topsoil salinity and mitigating associated alkalinity stress. This process also enhances soil enzyme activities and alters ionic dynamics, favoring a more balanced soil environment. The rhizospheric microbiome is improved, with increased diversity in beneficial phyla such as Proteobacteria and Actinobacteria, and modulated fungal genera including Alternaria and Fusarium. As a result of these changes, MNBs enhances cotton physiology, increasing activities of superoxide dismutase and peroxidase in cotton leaves, and potentially improving yield under varying salt stress levels.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: Mycological analysis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury reveals complex interactions between fungal pathogens, burn wounds, and industrial materials. The efficacy of antifungal treatments is compromised by the presence of toxic substances, such as heavy metals and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), in plastic and metal materials used in burn care. These toxins facilitate the growth of opportunistic fungi, including Aspergillus and Fusarium species, which exacerbate infection and impede healing. In one case study, a patient's burn wound developed a novel fungal community characterized by the co-occurrence of Aspergillus flavus and a bacterium, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which produced a previously unreported toxin. The resulting clinical outcome was a severe, treatment-resistant infection that ultimately led to the patient's death.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations of industrial landscapes suggest that microbial communities within Aspergillus fumigatus exhibit adaptive responses to azole-based fungicides, particularly in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes. Certain cyp51A SNPs, such as TR34 and TR46, facilitate the development of azole resistance by altering the target enzyme's affinity for the drug. The presence of multiple cyp51A SNPs, including TR34 and TR35, appears to further enhance resistance to azoles, underscoring the complexity of microbial resistance mechanisms. This multispecies assemblage of fungi, fungi-azole interaction, and industrial material exposure creates a dynamic environment that influences the emergence of resistance phenotypes in A. fumigatus. The cyp51A gene's polymorphism and its combinations facilitate the fungus's adaptation to industrial fungicides, signaling a shift in the ecological balance within these environments.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations from a site of environmental rupture reveal that the presence of industrial materials and infrastructure disrupts natural fungal dynamics. In areas surrounding human construction, Aspergillus fumigatus populations exhibit accelerated growth and adaptation, which may be attributed to the availability of novel substrates for colonization. A novel antifungal compound, produced in response to these human-induced disturbances, has been identified in the vicinity of affected Aspergillus fumigatus colonies. This compound targets the cell wall and cell membrane of Aspergillus fumigatus, inducing oxidative stress and inhibiting fungal growth. The emergence of this compound serves as an example of the complex, multispecies interactions that occur in response to human-induced environmental alterations.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations reveal that CuS nanoparticles stimulate a multifaceted defense response in tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) plants when applied to Fusarium-infected roots. Synthesis of CuS nanoparticles via a wet chemical method results in a product that exhibits high biocompatibility and antioxidant activity. The functionalization of CuS with green tea extract enhances the particle's ability to induce plant immunity, upregulating genes involved in systemic acquired resistance, salicylic acid biosynthesis, and phytoalexin production. This synergy between CuS and green tea extract triggers a cascade of defense mechanisms, ultimately reducing Fusarium wilt and promoting plant growth. At the nano-scale, CuS particles interact with fungal hyphae, disrupting membrane integrity and inducing cellular necrosis, while the green tea extract modulates the plant's immune response to optimize defense efficacy.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations of human-nonhuman interactions in the Anthropocene reveal a multitude of unintended consequences resulting from the imposition of human infrastructure. Industrial landscapes often serve as breeding grounds for novel fungal species, such as Fusarium graminearum, which exhibit adaptations to contaminated environments. Research on this species has led to the discovery of complex multispecies assemblages involving fungi, bacteria, and toxins, which interact with industrial materials in unpredictable ways. For instance, the incorporation of chemical pollutants into soil and water can alter the growth patterns and gene expression of Fusarium graminearum, potentially leading to the emergence of novel antifungal compounds with unknown ecological and health implications. Laboratory studies, such as the investigation of novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum through a combined genetic and chemical approach, highlight the need for continued research into the complex dynamics of human-nonhuman interactions in industrialized environments.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations on industrial landscapes reveal nonhuman responses to human infrastructure.  In areas with extensive chemical processing, fungi such as Aspergillus and Penicillium are observed to accumulate heavy metals, demonstrating an ability to thrive in contaminated environments.  Toxic substances like mercury and arsenic have been found to be stored within fungal mycelium, suggesting a complex interplay between microbial life and industrial waste.  In areas with high concentrations of plastics, certain bacteria exhibit enhanced biodegradation capabilities, breaking down polyethylene and polypropylene in response to environmental conditions.  Microbial assemblages have also been observed to interact with industrial materials, such as concrete and steel, in the formation of novel ecosystems, highlighting the capacity of nonhuman life to transform and adapt to human-made environments.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Observations of Aspergillus species in areas surrounding human infrastructure reveal a diverse molecular portrait. Aspergillus species exhibit a range of pathogenicity, impacting both humans and nonhuman organisms. In proximity to industrial materials, such as concrete and steel, Aspergillus species exhibit increased resistance to antifungal treatments. These resistant strains are more adept at colonizing and degrading these materials, often releasing toxins that accumulate in nearby ecosystems. Aspergillus-fungal-bacterial assemblages, influenced by industrial pollutants and climate change, are reconfiguring local microbial dynamics and producing unpredictable environmental effects.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: Research in the realm of fungal ecology has revealed the ubiquity of ETP-Type mycotoxins in fungal isolates within clinical contexts. These compounds, typically associated with environmental contamination, have been found to be produced by fungal species inhabiting the human body and infrastructure. Studies have demonstrated that the presence of these toxins within fungal isolates is indicative of a multispecies assemblage, where fungi interact with human-made materials, such as hospital equipment and building substrates. This interaction triggers the production of ETP-Type mycotoxins, which in turn contribute to the degradation of industrial materials, including steel and concrete. The resultant fungal-infused infrastructure represents a site of environmental rupture, where human and nonhuman agents converge to produce unforeseen, and potentially detrimental, effects.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: Decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, isolated from the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512, exhibit significant antibacterial and cytotoxic properties. These compounds have been found to disrupt membrane integrity in bacterial cells, leading to cell lysis and death. Notably, the alkaloids also demonstrated cytotoxic effects on human cancer cell lines, suggesting potential applications in cancer therapy. Furthermore, the fungus has been shown to produce other bioactive compounds, including secondary metabolites with antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory activities. The ability of this fungus to produce such a diverse array of bioactive compounds highlights its potential as a source of novel natural products for pharmaceutical and biotechnological applications.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations of human-nonhuman interactions reveal extensive fungal colonization of industrial materials, particularly those containing high levels of organic carbon and moisture. Smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network demonstrate potential for rapid and accurate mold identification in routine laboratory settings, significantly advancing diagnostic capabilities. In assemblages involving fungi, bacteria, and industrial materials, multispecies interactions often result in the degradation of infrastructure, as seen in the deterioration of building facades and water-damaged materials. The presence of toxins produced by certain mold species exacerbates this process, compromising structural integrity and posing health risks to humans. Furthermore, case studies reveal that fungi are capable of breaking down polymeric materials and metals, underscoring the need for a more nuanced understanding of the complex dynamics between human infrastructure and nonhuman assemblages.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Applied and Environmental Microbiology, Volume 92, Issue 1, January 2026.
summary: Observations at industrial sites reveal complex interactions between nonhuman species and human infrastructure. In a controlled environment, the fungus Aspergillus flavus exhibited enhanced aflatoxin production in the presence of nitric oxide, with the enzyme GSNOR (S-nitrosoglutathione reductase) playing a crucial role in maintaining nitric oxide homeostasis. This finding suggests a potential link between industrial pollutants and the biosynthesis of aflatoxins, toxic compounds produced by the fungus. In a separate study, bacteria isolated from abandoned chromium mining sites demonstrated adaptation to and degradation of industrial chromium waste, a process facilitated by unique enzyme systems and microbial consortia. The presence of toxic substances such as aflatoxins and heavy metals like chromium was found to induce changes in microbial metabolisms, resulting in unanticipated and excessive production of secondary metabolites.
